user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileOpen_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileOpen_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const char *local_path, int32 flags, int32 access_mode)
{
    int                             os_perm;
    int                             os_mode;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    /*
    ** Check for a valid access mode
    ** For creating a file, OS_READ_ONLY does not make sense
    */
    switch (access_mode)
    {
        case OS_WRITE_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_WRONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_ONLY:
            os_perm = O_RDONLY;
            break;
        case OS_READ_WRITE:
            os_perm = O_RDWR;
            break;
        default:
            return OS_ERROR;
    }

    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_CREATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_CREAT;
    }
    if (flags & OS_FILE_FLAG_TRUNCATE)
    {
        os_perm |= O_TRUNC;
    }

    os_perm |= OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS;

    os_mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR | S_IRGRP | S_IWGRP | S_IROTH | S_IWOTH;

    impl->fd = open(local_path, os_perm, os_mode);

    if (impl->fd < 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("open(%s): %s\n", local_path, strerror(errno));
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    /*
     * If the flags included O_NONBLOCK, then
     * enable the "select" call on this handle.
     */
    impl->selectable = ((os_perm & O_NONBLOCK) != 0);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_FileOpen_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_READ_ONLY 0
...
#define OS_WRITE_ONLY 1
...
#define OS_READ_WRITE 2
...
extern const int OS_IMPL_REGULAR_FILE_FLAGS
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
int         fd
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the function and related declarations for any compiler-specific language extensions (examples: __attribute__, __asm__, asm, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values, Microsoft __declspec, GCC/Clang extensions, inline assembly, nonstandard keywords, or other compiler-specific tokens). None are present in the provided code. The variadic macro OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) is a standard C99 feature (variadic macros), and static inline is standard C99. The use of POSIX APIs/macros (open, O_RDONLY, O_CREAT, S_IRUSR, etc.) are platform APIs, not compiler language extensions. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET uses address-of on the supplied expression but does not rely on any compiler extension. Therefore there are no code fragments that appear to use compiler language extensions that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
